717152f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Park Row
717152f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Park Row, showing buildings on the westerly side facing City Hall Park. This civic area lies between these two thoroughfares, being at the apex formed by their convergence. At the left margin is a portion of the old Astor House, this being the S.W. corner of Barclay Street. The block front above (to Park Place) was the site of the Woolworth Building in 1912.

About 1860's

America Studio, photo
87 Nassau St., N.Y.C

Gift of Urbrock Collection

717159f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Park Row
717159f-a.text:
Broadway and Park Row convergence as photographec northward from the old Astor House lying between Vesey and Barclay Streets. Broadway is to the left and Park Row is on the right. Note the absence of the old U. S. Post
Office at the apex in the Park.
About 1860e
American Studio, photo
87 Nassau Street, N.Y.7.
Gift of Urbrock Collection
REPRODUCTION RICRTE UNRNOwN

717150f-a.text:

of this section of N.Y. by Brady
Recruiting Station for the Civil War

Photo By

717151f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Park Row
717151f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, north from but not including Park Row. This picture is one of the first photos taken of New York City.
It was made from a wet plate negative.
About 1863.
Brown Brothers.

717162f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Park Row
717162f-a.text:
Broadway &. Park Row, north from their convergence at Vesey Street, showing the old U. S. Post Offiee at the apex of City Hall Park. Note the completion or roof repairs. At the left is the Astor House, occupying the Broadway frontage from Vesey
to Barclay Street's..
Ne6 ~ E2S
About 1880
Gift of 'rbrock Collection

722430f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Broadway
722430f-a.text:
Park Row, south from the Brooklyn Bridge, to and including Broadway. The view shows in the foreground, the new (then) pedestrian approach to the Brooklyn Bridge Station of the Second and Third Aves., Elevated. Adjoining same is the Pulitzer Building, with the spire of the Tribune Building overshadowing the Times Building, on the right. Iu the distant background, at the southern extremity of Park Row, at Broadway, is observed St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Chapel. Directly on the right. is the Hall of Records, built as a City Jail about 1775.
About 1880.

722431f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Broadway
722431f-a.text:
Park Row, aouth from the Brooklyn Bridge, to and including Broadway. The view shows on the extreme right, the old Hall of Records, with the City Hall further westward. In the direct center, is the old U.S.P.O.. with the Times Building on the opposite side of the street. At the head of Park Row, at Broadway, appears St. Paul's Church and Grounds. Note the horse drawn cars. Bridge shown, in the the foreground, Was an extension from the Brooklyn Bridge Station of the Manhattan Elevated Lines.
About 18B4.
New York Edison Co.

717118f.text:
V S J
Broadway,North West corner,Barclay to Vesey Streets, and shouing the old Astor House,since demolished and St.Paul's
Chapel.
(2)The same,closer view.
About 1885.
Urbrock Collection,

717136f-a.text:
Broadway,West Side,between Barclay and Vesey Streets,
showing the old Astor House.
About 1885.
Urbrock Collection,
Credit Line Imperative.

717138f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, at Barclay Street, showing the sites pf the future Transportation and Woolworth Bldgs. The former rose in 1926 at the S. W. corner that now is the northerly half of the old Astor Hotse. The severel structures at the right forming the block frontage from Barclay iitreet to Park Place will be removed in 1912
for the distinctive Woolworth Building.
About 1890
Roege, photo
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

717131f.text:
Broadway, south from Barclay Street (right), showing cables being laid on the east side of this thoroughfare and slightly north of the Astor House, which appears on the right. South of the latter is St. Pauls Chapel.. On the left is a portion of the Post Office, at the convergence of Broadway and Park Row. Across the latter are structures
on the east side of same, at Ann Street.
About 1890.

717117f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Park Row
717117f-a.text:
Broadway at Park Row.
"248. Astor House & St. Pauls, 1893.'

722432f-b.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Broadway
722432f-b.text:
(1)At the intersection of Park Row and Broadway...shown is Park Row north from and including Broadway, to and including the Brooklyn Bridge Approach (between Frankfort and North William Streets). The view shows the General Post Office at the intersection of Broadway and Park Row.  In the background is the municipal building.
July 30, 1930
P.L. Sperr.

(2) The same showing a further view northward on Broadway, east side.  Note horse drawn street cars, open barauch, overhead wires and gas street lamps.
About 1900.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

722432f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Broadway
722432f-a.text:
(1)At the intersection of Park Row and Broadway...shown is Park Row north from and including Broadway, to and including the Brooklyn Bridge Approach (between Frankfort and North William Streets). The view shows the General Post Office at the intersection of Broadway and Park Row.  In the background is the municipal building.
July 30, 1930
P.L. Sperr.

(2) The same showing a further view northward on Broadway, east side.  Note horse drawn street cars, open barauch, overhead wires and gas street lamps.
About 1900.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

717145f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, south from and including Barclay (foreground) to Dey (extreme left) Streets, showing prominently the Aator House, which occupies the block between Barclay and Vesey Streets. South of same, on the Vesey to Fulton Streets block, appears St. Pauls P.E. Chapel and Grounds. The spired structure, in the same direction is the 11-story Western Union Building, No. 195 Broadway, at the N.W. corner of Dey Street. Shown on the right are Nos. 229 and 231 Broadway, at and adjoining the N.Wu. corner of Barclay Street.
June 3, 1904.
Brown Brothers.

717119f-a.text:
Broadway, south from Barclay Street, showing this thoroughfare below City Hall Park. At the right is the old Astor House, occupying the frontage from Barclay to Vesey Street's. Inthe block below, Vesey to Fulton St's., 1s St. Pauls Chapel. The old Evening Mail and the towering Singer Building overshadow these. Dn the left is the St. Paul Building on the old P. T. Barnum site. Park Row converges with Broadway at this point; transportation is provided by the Third Avenue R. R. Co. on this artery, and a
atreet car of same appears thereupon.
About 1910
Gift of Urbrock Collection

717172f-a.text:
7233 Broadway,showing the Woolworth Building,60 stories high located at that site. The building has an elevation of
792 feet,
November 20th,I9I2.
Copyrighted by,
Underhill,
No Reproductions.

717170f-b.text:
Broadway, west side, from Barclay Street to Park Place, showing the Woolworth Building at this location. Note the constructional details atop the tower in both views. The smaller view is obviously in a northward direction from the old Western Union Building and includes the spire of St. Pauls Chapel and the old Astor House in the toreground. At the right is the old U. S. Post Office with a glimpse of the City Hall above same. The 1 story Emigrant Industrid
Bank rises above the latter.
1912-3
International News Service
(larger view)
Gift or Urbrock Collection
REPRODUCTION RIORTS URENON
Gift of Urbrock Collection

The smaller view is obviously in a northward direction from the old Western Union Building and includes the spire of St. Pauls Chapel and the old Astor House in the toreground. At the right is the old U. S. Post Office with a glimpse of the City Hall above same. The 1 story Emigrant Industrid

717171f-c.text:
229-237 Broadway, west side, from Barclay Street to Park Place, showing at this location, the 55 story Woolworth Bldg. The general direction is northward from a vantage point at No. 165 Broadway (City Investing H1d2.) in views 1, 2, and 3. View 4 is photographed from No. 30 Church Street. Broadway is the thoroughfare clearly shown at the right. Note the spire of St. Pauls Chapel, the quadrangular Astor House, the ornate Post Office, City Hall Park and the white marble Sun (formerly A. C. Stewarts) Building. The St. Paul ldg. ppears at the right margin of views 1 and 3. Today, (1939) this view is Nmore or less the same. The most radical change is the replacement of the old Astor House by the 44 storied Transportation Bldg. and the present demolition of the Post Office.
View 1 March 1912
2 June 1912
3January 19, 1917 NEG P~ S629
4August 11, 1925 N E, Ei W6IE
0ift of W. A. Lucas

717174f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from Barclay Street (right) to Park Place (left) showing the Woolworth Building at this site. View is eastward from the air towards the East River and its Brooklyn shore. City Hall Park is at the left. Flanking the dominant structure are, the World, the Tribune and the Park Row buildings. The old U. S. Post Office buflding is obstructed from view.
About 1928
Copyrighted by
Major Hamilton Maxwell

717182f-b.text:
(1)
220 to 259 Broadway, west side, north from Barclay (left) to Warren (right) Streets, as viewed in a southwesterly direction from the Municipal Building and across City Hall Park. Prominently shown are the Transportation, Woolworth and New York Telephone Buildings all silhouetted against the North (Hudson) River. In the left foreground
is the roof of the City Hall.
June 23, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, minus No. 258-259, the Rogers Peet Building, at the S.E. corner of Warren Street. Shown in the left foreground of this view is the old United States Post Office located in the southern tip of City
Hall Park.
June 12, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, exclusive of the oolworth Building, No. 229-237 Broadway, from Barclay Street to Park Place. On the right of this view appears a 12-story structure, No. 260-261 Broadway, at the N.d. corner of Warren Street, and a 5-story building, No. 265, adjoining same.
June 23, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

717177f-b.text:
229-237 Broadway, west side, from Barclay Street to Park Place, showing at that location the 55 story Woolworth Building. The photographer's vantage point is between the arches of the Municipal Building and he is viewing southwestward across Centre Street, City Hall Park and the east wing of the City Hall. Note the subway kiosks thru which entrance is made to the Brooklyn Bridge Station underground.

April 29, 1937.
Views 1 and 2

W.P.A. Photo
Five Boroughs Project

717166f.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Park Row
717166f.text:
Broadway (leftl and Park Row (ricNtV above Vesey Street, showing the old General Post Office and Federal Bldg. on the day demolition actually startec on the outside. This structure, erected about 63 years ago at a cost of 8,500, 000 is to be removed to allow City Hall Park to return to its original contour. For a photo of same from the same point of vantage (The N. f. Telephone &. Telegraph Bldg.)
see files under City Hall Park.
September 9, 1938
Robert A. Knudtsen
221 E. 31at St., N.Y.C.

717168f-a.text:
Broadway (left) and Park Row (right), north from Ann Street, showing demolition of the old U. S. Post Office. A portion of the
Woolworth Buildings forms the left margin.
1939

This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. y.' by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.
